Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Citizens' Social Group Stereotypes as a Basis for Political Reasoning.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Early work in political science indicated that citizens structure their political attitudes around 'visible social groupings' meaning that, in an effort to simplify political choices, citizens turn questions of policy into moral judgments about the groups involved (Converse 1964). However, much of the research on citizens' group-centric attitudes has neglected a primary means by which citizens organize and evaluate one another: economic differences. This oversight is surprising, considering the recent scholarly and media attention given to rising inequality.

In order to fill this gap, the Co-PI is undertaking a multi-stage dissertation project that examines the manner in which citizens use stereotypes about economic groups as a shortcut for selecting candidates and determining which policies to support. Using a two-stage data collection project comprised of a nationally representative survey and a follow-up survey experiment, the Co-PI will examine the beliefs that citizens have about these groups and how these beliefs are consequential for political reasoning. The proposed study will address three questions. First, what is the nature of the public's beliefs about economic groups? Second, how are these beliefs consequential for citizens? policy attitudes? Third, recognizing that these attitudes may not be fixed and are susceptible to priming, under which conditions are these beliefs more or less significant for public opinion?

This proposal addresses a double-sided blindness in the existing research in political science. While inequality scholars have addressed the institutional causes and consequences of rising inequality, they have been slower to evaluate links between the changing composition of social groups and group-centered political behavior. Conversely, while political psychologists have produced abundant work on racial and gender stereotypes, they have discounted economic differences. The line of questioning proposed here builds on and contributes to key debates in both political psychology and the study of inequality, in addition to identifying the real world political consequences of such attitudes.

Broader Impacts
Research on economic differences is especially timely. Over the past few decades, inequality has risen at an alarming rate, while mobility has stagnated. The New York Times declaration that we are in a 'New Gilded Age' all suggest that economic-based groupings have become increasingly salient to voters and, in turn, influential for both public opinion and political outcomes.

In order to maximize the impact of the proposed study, the Co-PI plans to make the data publicly available as well as easy to incorporate into other datasets. In doing so, this data-collection project will hopefully facilitate a wide array of studies that are not considered in the Co-PI's dissertation and will provide a theoretical and data-driven starting point for additional research on economic status and public opinion as well as (when matched to higher-level data) representation and broader economic factors.

The Co-PI will also submit the research proposed here to scholarly conferences and journals in order to disseminate insights about the attitudes that are relevant to political behavior to a wide audience and provide a methodological precedent for future research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past few decades, economic inequality has risen at an alarming rate while class mobility has stagnated. But, what is the nature of the public’s beliefs about the rich? And how are these beliefs consequential for citizens’ voting behavior and policy attitudes? Using an original survey and an embedded series of survey experiments, I illustrate that citizens’ attitudes towards the rich are consequential for both citizens’ policy preferences and their vote choice.

I examine the content of stereotypes about the rich using a large-scale original survey, the 2014 Study on the Attitudes Towards the Rich (SATR) (N=2,267). I find that the American public is ambivalent about the rich—perceiving them as smarter, more capable, more competent, and more conservative than other groups, but also less empathic and less compassionate. Americans also feel less close to the rich than they do to other groups; they perceive them as receiving special breaks from the government, as threatening the middle and working class, as experiencing better treatment from the political system, and as having considerably more sway in the political process than other groups.

Using the SATR, I examine the consequences of these beliefs for citizens’ policy preferences. I briefly outline a broad conceptual model that theorizes how citizens might use their stereotypes about rich people for political reasoning. Then, using the SATR, I define seven dimensions of beliefs about the rich: Empathy, Competence, Closeness, Unearned Wealth, Special Government Treatment, Undue Influence, and Threat to the Middle/Working Class. I explore how each of these dimensions is associated with support for a variety of economic policies. It turns out that negative stereotypes about the rich are strongly and consistently associated with liberal policy preferences even once we account for the effect of the usual suspects—such as partisan identification, income, subjective social class identity, and ideology. 

Then, I explore the role of stereotypes about the rich in an electoral context, and present evidence from three survey experiments that manipulate the social class of hypothetical political candidates. I find that voters penalize wealthy candidates when their wealth is associated with big business or Wall Street. Voters perceive such candidates as less empathic and are less likely to vote for them. When a candidate’s wealth is associated with a helping profession (e.g., medicine) and an elite education, voters perceive the candidate as significantly more competent than their control or working class counterparts and show no preference or penalty in their vote intentions. Across the board, however, wealthy candidates are perceived as holding more conservative policy positions relative to their counterparts. Additionally, citizens’ – especially Democrats’ – predispositions about the rich in general figure into their evaluations of wealthy politicians. 

In my conclusion, I ask a final question: do attitudes towards wealthy citizens and wealthy politicians have implications for peoples' evaluation of their representation more broadly? If people have negative stereotypes about the rich and are cognizant of the fact that their representatives are also rich, it is possible that they connect the dots in their overall evaluations of their representative. In a series of OLS models, I find that higher estimates of congressional salary, congressional median net worth, and peoples' own representatives’ net worth is strongly and consistently correlated with peoples’ negative views of politicians, negative views Congress as a whole, and negative evaluations of peoples' own representative.
